I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The  Government  of  Uzbekistan  requested  assistance  for  developing  an  enabling 
environment to promote free and fair competition, increase efficiency and productivity, and 
protect consumer interests. A Fact-Finding Mission visited Tashkent from 10 to 22 February 
2003  and  reached  an  understanding  with  the  Government  on  the  objectives,  scope,  cost, 
financing, and implementation arrangements for the technical assistance (TA).1 The TA logical 
framework is given in Appendix 1.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Competition Policy.  An effective competition policy promotes efficient allocation of 
resources and economic growth, includes an appropriate regulatory environment based on 
detailed and clear legislation focusing on regulating anticompetitive behavior (all participants 
know the “rules of the game” and what they need to do to avoid breaching them), and promotes 
good governance by diminishing the opportunities for rent seeking behavior and corruption. In 
transition economies, competition policy is often associated with fair trade, resulting in a legal 
framework  designed  to  protect  small  competitors  rather  than  to  promote  efficiency. 
Governments often question the value of competition, raising concerns that it will expose small 
local enterprises to extinction from large multinationals.  
 
3.  There  is  a  limited  understanding  of  the  basic  concepts  of  competition  policy  in 
Uzbekistan. In contrast to approaches adopted in more developed markets that focus on the 
regulation of anticompetitive behavior and in other transition economies, the current regulatory 
framework relies primarily on the imposition of price controls on enterprises based on the size of 
their  market  share  or  sector  engaged  in  (natural  monopolies).  Once  these  “monopoly 
enterprises” are identified, they are placed in a Register of Monopoly Enterprises (the Register), 
and price controls are imposed by the Ministry of Finance (MOF). As of 1 January 2003, 386 
enterprises were categorized as monopolies, providing 247 types of products.2   
 
4.  Natural monopolies are broadly defined to include any enterprise engaged in energy 
(including  transportation  thereof),  transport,  telecommunications,  and  water  and  water 
treatment. The Government plans to restructure 23 large enterprises in many of these sectors 
under its ongoing case-by-case privatization program.3 Major enterprises in the privatization list 
include  Uzbek  Telecom  (telecommunications),  Uzbekneftegaz  (oil  and  gas  sector),  and 
Uzbekistan Temir Yullari (rail).  The absence of an effective competition policy and adequate 
regulatory  mechanisms  for  the  sectors  being  restructured  could  result  in  the  transfer  of 
monopoly power from the public to the private sector or the maintenance of the status quo.  
 
5.  The World Bank and the TACIS Technical Dissemination Project (TDP) provided TA to 
the State Committee on Demonopolization and Competition Development (CDCD) in 2001/2002 
for developing proposals to amend the legislative framework to move toward more behavior-
based regulation4 and to incorporate European Union directives, respectively. Under the World

6.  Company Ownership Structure and Its Implication for Competition. Although there 
are more than 4,700 joint stock companies (JSCs) in Uzbekistan, approximately 3,000 continue 
to be state owned or controlled. The remaining 1,700 are privately owned. The Government's 
ownership interest is managed by the State Property Committee (GOS Kom Imushestvo) which 
appoints state trustees for JSCs in which it owns 25% or more of equity capital (932 JSCs) and 
trustee managers for JSCs in which it owns less than 25% of equity capital (2,068 JSCs). State 
trustees and trustee managers sit on the supervisory boards of JSCs and until recently, could 
veto  any  supervisory  board  decision.  Most  JSCs  belong  to  production  trade  associations 
(PTAs), former line ministries that are heavily involved in the business operations of their 
members, including resource quotas and price controls.       
 
7.  On 24 January 2003, a presidential decree “On Measures for Fundamental Increase of 
Private Sector’s Share and Importance in the Economy of Uzbekistan”5 was issued to facilitate 
private sector development and promote a more competitive business environment. Among 
other  things,  this  decree  incorporated  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  recommendations, 
including removal of the preferential voting rights of state trustees and managers who are 
members of a JSC supervisory board and the right of PTAs to interfere in the operations of their 
members.6 CDCD will need to develop and implement a strategy to monitor PTA compliance 
with this decree. 
 
8.  Legal and Regulatory Framework. International best practice standards promote the 
adoption of competition laws to prevent businesses from engaging in anticompetitive practices 
that  increase  their  profitability  at  the  expense  of  consumers  and  efficient  operation  of  the 
market.  Sound  economic  analysis  is  incorporated  into  the  review  of  allegations  of 
anticompetitive behavior. As these jurisdictions deregulate monopoly positions, competition laws 
are complemented by sector-specific regulations.   
 
9.  The  current  legal  and  regulatory  framework  in  Uzbekistan  ignores  case-by-case 
economic analysis of monopolistic behavior and instead imposes price controls on firms based 
solely on market share. Application of a market share standard in Uzbekistan is difficult because 
of current market distortions (subsidies, exclusion of state-controlled firms from regulation).  The 
legal framework does not address issues relating to the unbundling of “natural monopolies” that 
are currently being privatized. New regulations are needed to ensure that enterprises that have 
been unbundled have access to inputs and services that may only be available to incumbent 
firms, many of which may continue to be state owned or controlled.  
 
10.  A draft proposal to amend the Competition Law was recently prepared by CDCD to 
address some of these issues. However, initial review of the legislation indicates that the focus 
of regulation may still be to regulate enterprises with a dominant market share (35%) that may 
be  engaged  in  anticompetitive  behavior.  In  addition,  the  draft  continues  to  require  CDCD 
approval of acquisitions of 35% or more of an enterprise and mergers/business combinations,

11.  Institutional  Framework  for  Competition  Policy  Implementation.  CDCD  was 
established as a department of MOF in 1992 and transformed into an “independent” state 
committee in 2000. However, CDCD is not operationally independent. It is required to report to 
the cabinet of ministers, members of which have vested interests in maintaining the status quo.  
 
12.  As set forth in the Competition Law, although CDCD is responsible for demonopolization 
and competition development, its primary function has been to determine which enterprises are 
acting as monopolies for purposes of imposing price controls and sanctions.  CDCD is headed 
by a chairman appointed by the cabinet of ministers and approved by parliament. It has a core 
central staff of 50 persons and thus relies heavily on regional staff (342 staff at 14 regional 
offices) to help monitor JSCs for compliance with the current legal and regulatory framework, 
including detection of “monopolies” and anticompetitive conduct.  
 
13.  A majority of regional office staff resources are allocated to the maintenance of the 
register system. Proposed amendments to the Competition Law, which incorporate behavior- 
based factors into the determination of whether an enterprise is acting as a monopoly that 
should be subject to price controls and evaluation of mergers, will require CDCD to transform 
from an analytical, research body to a regulatory body with an emphasis on investigation.  
Investigative standards to determine anticompetitive behavior involve complicated statistical 
analyses, careful review and understanding of the details of business records of individual firms, 
subjective judgments about basic issues such as product definition and substitution, proof of 
intent, etc.  Merger analysis is equally complex.  
 
14.  Eighty five percent of CDCD staff, economists trained under the former Soviet system, 
have limited understanding of and are incapable of analyzing market structure and performance. 
The  World  Bank  has  provided  training  to  mid-level  staff  on  how  to  conduct  case-by-case 
investigations and analysis centering on firm behavior, promotion of competition, and analysis of 
an individual firm’s economic power.8   
 
15.  External controls on anticompetitive behavior are weak and based on poor corporate 
governance practices and lack of understanding of the role of competition in a market economy.  
Key decision makers, including other government bodies and the judiciary, whose support is 
needed to effectively transform CDCD’s role, do not have a basic understanding of competition 
and related policies and economic impact.  
 
16.  Operations and Strategy of ADB and Other Aid Sources. ADB is supporting the 
Government in the restructuring and liquidation of state-owned enterprises within the broader 
framework of reform of corporate governance and enterprise restructuring. ADB provided TA9 in 
2000 to, among other things, review the adequacy of the policy and institutional framework for 
corporate  governance  and  facilitate  capacity  building  activities  to  promote  private  sector

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Purpose and Output 
 
17.  The  TA  will  help  promote  private  sector  growth  by  creating  a  better  enabling 
environment to promote development of a more competitive and healthy enterprise sector that 
better protects consumers. To achieve this goal, the TA will (i) help the Government develop a 
comprehensive strategy for promoting competition, (ii) support incorporation of behavior-based 
regulation into the legal and regulatory framework and enhance the ability of CDCD to evaluate 
anticompetitive  behavior  and  proposed  mergers,  and  (iii)  develop  recommendations  for 
regulating natural monopolies.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
18.  This TA will include the following activities:  
 
(i)  Competition  Policy  and  Macroeconomic  and  Regulatory  Assessment.              
(a) assessment of the impact of recent government decrees and resolutions 
governing the role of PTAs and CDCD plans to implement new requirements and 
prohibitions; (b) assessment of the impact of CDCD’s current demonopolization 
program; (c) assessment of the impact of the current framework on restructuring 
and privatization of enterprises presently regulated as natural monopolies; (d) 
development  of  an  intergovernmental  committee  comprised  of  key  decision 
makers  to  formulate  a  strategy  for  promoting  competition  and  ensuring 
consistency  in  the  application  of  government  policies;  and  (e)  workshop  to 
discuss findings and key policy issues that need to be addressed; 
 
(ii)  Competition  Law.  (a)  assessment  of  current  and  proposed  framework  for 
regulating  competition,  including  the  role  and  independence  of  CDCD  in 
regulating competition and the role or other government agencies/departments; 
(b) application to state-owned and -controlled entities (enterprises, PTAs, etc.);      
(c)  review  of  the  institutional  framework  for  regulating  competition  in 
Commonwealth of Independent States countries (CIS), including other Central 
Asian Republics (CARs);  (d) recommendations to address perceived gaps and 
implementation issues; and (e) workshop to clarify options; and 
 
(iii)  Natural  Monopoly  Law.  (a)  assessment  of  the  impact  of  the  current  legal 
framework on restructuring of natural monopolies; (b) survey of the experience of 
CIS countries, including other CARs, with the legal and institutional framework for 
regulating natural monopolies and public utilities that have been unbundled and

C.  Cost and Financing 
 
19.  The estimated cost of the TA is $430,000 equivalent, including a foreign exchange cost 
of $225,000 and a local currency cost of $205,000 equivalent. The entire foreign exchange cost 
and  local currency cost of $75,000 equivalent will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s TA 
funding program. The Government will contribute $130,000 in kind for office space, counterpart 
staff, transportation, and other services. Details of the cost estimates are provided in Appendix 
2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
20.  CDCD will be the Executing Agency and will provide the necessary office support, 
counterpart staff, transportation, and other services to the consultants. ADB will review and 
monitor the implementation of the TA through missions and consultants’ reports. 
 
21.  The TA will be tendered to an international firm. The consultants will be selected and 
recruited using a biodata technical proposal in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants  and  other  arrangements  satisfactory  to  ADB  on  the  engagement  of  domestic 
consultants, using the quality and cost-based selection method.  A team of consultants–three 
international and four domestic–will be engaged by ADB to implement the TA for a total of 25.6 
person-months. The international consultants will include a team leader/economist-competition 
policy  expert  (3.3  person-months),  a  regulatory  expert  (competition  and  enforcement)  (1.3 
person-months), and a regulatory expert (natural monopolies) (1 person-month). The domestic 
consultants  will  include  a  competition  policy  specialist/s  (8  person-months),  a  regulatory 
specialist (competition and enforcement) (4 person-months), a regulatory specialist (natural 
monopolies) (2 person-months), and a project administration specialist (6 person-months). The 
terms of reference for the consultants are in Appendix 3. The TA will support training, seminars, 
and workshops, which will be done by the consultants in close coordination with CDCD and 
ADB. Equipment procurement will be carried out in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for 
Procurement.  
 
22.  The TA is expected to begin in September 2003 and will be implemented over a period 
of 25 months, finishing in September 2005. The team leader will submit (i) an inception report 2 
weeks  after  commencement  of  their  services,  (ii)  quarterly  progress  reports  during 
implementation,  (iii) a draft final report before the conclusion of the contract, and (iv) the final 
report 2 weeks after incorporating comments from CDCD and ADB.   
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
23.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $300,000 on a grant basis to 
the  Government  of  Uzbekistan  for  Institutional  Strengthening  of  the  State  Committee  on 
Demonopolization and Competition Development, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International Consultants (5.6 person-months) 
 
1.  A team of three international experts will be recruited to assist the State Committee on 
Demonopolization and Competition Development (CDCD). The terms of reference are provided 
to outline indicative tasks, and the consultants will be required to undertake any other related 
tasks to attain the objectives of the technical assistance (TA).  
 
1.  Team Leader/Economist/Competition Policy Expert  
            (3.3 person-months) 
 
2.  The team leader/economist-competition policy expert should have an advanced degree 
in economics and at least 10 years experience in competition policy in countries in transition. 
This consultant will be responsible for the overall management of TA implementation and the 
timely delivery of quality interim and final reports. He/she should identify the macroeconomic 
impact of current policies and recommended changes, and provide policy recommendations on 
proposed amendments to the Competition Law, the proposed framework to regulate natural 
monopolies, and the proposed by-laws/regulations/procedures designed to promote competition 
and provide for market based prices. In particular, the consultant will 
 
(i)  provide an overview of the international experience and economic reasons for 
regulating competition, including regulation of natural monopolies and mergers, 
and issues relating to economic objectives, with application of such concepts in a 
transition economy (Commonwealth of Independent States countries); 
 
(ii)  analyze data to determine the economic boundaries of markets/firms’ market 
share based on questions of product substitutability and geographic limits of total 
delivered product costs relative to demand (data collection and analysis should 
be focused on the worst offenders); 
 
(iii)  evaluate  the  extent  to  which  current  horizontal  and  vertical  structures  (in 
production  trade  associations  [PTAs]  and  holding  companies)  are 
anticompetitive; 
 
(iv)  evaluate the methodology for determining monopolies; 
 
(v)  identify policy, regulatory and institutional reforms that need to be introduced to 
promote competition in pricing, acquisition of shares, and mergers; 
 
(vi)  prepare an explanation of formulas and mechanisms for CDCD to determine 
dominant market positions (monopolies) and natural monopolies, and evaluate 
mergers;   
 
(vii)  evaluate the economic impact of CDCD’s demonopolization program;  
 
(viii)  participate in a workshop with key decision makers to discuss project findings 
and key policy issues; and 
 
(ix)  prepare a matrix of sequenced policy recommendations to promote competition 
and provide for market-based prices.

2.  Regulatory Expert (Competition and Enforcement) (1.3 person-months) 
 
3.  The regulatory expert (competition and enforcement) should have an advanced degree 
in finance, law, or a related field and at least 10 years experience in regulation of competition. 
Recent consulting experience in this area, preferably in a transition economy, is essential. This 
expert will 
 
(i)  provide  an  overview  of  the  institutional  and  policy  framework  for  regulating 
competition,  including  the  role  of  other  government  agencies,  holding 
companies/PTAs, and mergers and acquisitions; 
 
(ii)  review  and  highlight  gaps  and  inconsistencies,  as  well  as  restraints  to 
competition and the promotion of private enterprises in current and proposed 
legislation,  orders,  decrees,  regulations,  guidelines,  etc.  (collectively 
“regulations”); note regulations that incorporate recent recommendations of other 
donors (e.g., move to behavior-based regulation) and the status thereof; 
 
(iii)  organize and participate in a workshop with key decision makers to disseminate 
and discuss findings and develop a new regulatory strategy;  
 
(iv)  review  regulatory  standards  and  guidelines  for  detecting  horizontal  restraints 
(price fixing, input or output restraints, market allocation, restriction of market 
access, bid rigging, etc.), vertical restraints (resale price maintenance, exclusive 
dealings, exclusive geographic designations, tying arrangements, boycotts, and 
refusals to deal), and unilateral restraints (predatory pricing and other means of 
raising  entry  costs  for  rivals);  identify  gaps  therein  (written  standards, 
implementation,  etc.);  draft  proposals  to  address  such  gaps  (including  those 
prepared with external assistance); and conduct workshops with relevant CDCD 
staff to clarify options, including investigations of hypothetical situations involving 
an abuse of dominant position by a firm; and 
 
(v)  assist  the  team  leader  in  preparing  a  matrix  of  sequenced  policy 
recommendations to promote competition, focusing on the legal and regulatory 
framework. 
 
3.  Regulatory Expert (Natural Monopolies) (1 person-month) 
 
4.  The regulatory expert (natural monopolies) will have an advanced degree in finance, 
law, or a related field and at least 10 years experience in regulation of natural monopolies/public 
utilities.  Recent  consulting  experience  in  this  area,  preferably  in  a  transition  economy,  is 
essential. This expert will 
 
(i)  provide  an  overview  of  the  institutional  and  policy  framework  for  regulating 
natural monopolies, including those being restructured, and the role of other 
government agencies;  
 
(ii)  review  regulatory  proposals  prepared  by  other  donors  and  discuss  such 
proposals  with  CDCD  staff  to  understand  why  they  have/have  not  been 
incorporated or implemented;

(iii)  conduct a workshop with relevant CDCD staff and key decision makers to clarify 
policy and regulatory options, identify implementation issues, and develop a new 
strategy to regulate natural monopolies, including public utilities that have been 
and will be unbundled and privatized; and 
 
(iv)  assist  the  team  leader  in  preparing  a  matrix  of  sequenced  policy 
recommendations to regulate natural monopolies. 
 
B.  Domestic Consultants (20 person-months) 
 
5.  Domestic consultants will be recruited to assist the international consulting team. These 
consultants should have extensive in-depth local industry knowledge and good contacts in the 
area of regulation of competition and natural monopolies, including utilities that have been 
unbundled (telecoms, oil and gas, rail). The domestic consultants will assist the international 
consultants in quickly becoming familiar with their tasks by translating various documents into 
English  and  researching  and  compiling  a  set  of  government  policies,  regulations,  and 
procedures adopted. The domestic consultants are expected to possess sufficient experience in 
their respective fields, and will include a competition policy specialist (8 person-months) with a 
solid  background  and  experience  in  regulation  of  competition  in  Uzbekistan;  regulatory 
specialist  (competition  and  enforcement,  4  person-months)  with  a  solid  background  in 
Uzbekistan  legislation  and  normative  acts  related  to  competition,  and  having  experience 
working with CDCD; regulatory specialist (natural monopolies, 2 person-months) with a solid 
background in Uzbekistan legislation and  normative acts related to the regulation of natural 
monopolies,  having  experience  working  with  CDCD,  and  with  solid  knowledge  in  the 
privatization of utilities (laws/legislations/process); and a project administration specialist (6 
person-months) with an accounting/finance background to assist the team leader with project 
management and administration.
